awd_titl_txt: Bridging Linguistic Fieldwork and Psycholinguistics to Investigate Reflexive Processing
awd_abstract_narration:
This award was provided as part of NSF's Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences (SBE) Postdoctoral Research Fellowships (SPRF) program and SBE's Linguistics program. The goal of the SPRF program is to prepare promising, early career doctoral-level scientists for scientific careers in academia, industry or private sector, and government. SPRF awards involve two years of training under the sponsorship of established scientists and encourage Postdoctoral Fellows to perform independent research. NSF seeks to promote the participation of scientists from all segments of the scientific community, including those from underrepresented groups, in its research programs and activities; the postdoctoral period is considered to be an important level of professional development in attaining this goal. Each Postdoctoral Fellow must address important scientific questions that advance their respective disciplinary fields. Under the sponsorship of Dr. Brian Dillon at the University of Massachusetts Amherst, this postdoctoral fellowship award supports an early career scientist investigating how speakers understand pronouns in real-time. The goal of this project is to better understand the complex mental processes that make language comprehension seem effortless for many adults in their native language. This project will focus on how unique grammatical features, such as word order and complex voice system, shape the real-time comprehension of pronouns. More broadly, the goal of this project is to help us better understand the relative contributions of sentence structure (syntax) and sentence meaning (semantics) in real-time language comprehension. A better understanding of how humans use linguistic information to understand language can in turn help in the development of natural language processing systems to allow computers to better approximate human language use.

The project investigates these questions by exploring how comprehenders process reflexives in real-time. Reflexive pronouns are pronouns that are subject to strict syntactic and semantic licensing requirements, and can be used to understand how rapidly these sources of information are used to constrain comprehension. To examine the relative contributions of structural information (e.g., c-command and syntactic locality) and semantic information (e.g., thematic roles), the researcher will deploy a series of experiments using the Visual World paradigm. The experiments in this project will measure the extent to which comprehenders attend to different referents over time to better understand how quickly and accurately comprehenders identify the antecedent of a reflexive. The project will yield the first comprehensive set of linguistic and psycholinguistic data on the comprehension of reflexives. The project's results will also help establish the methodological validity of using the visual world paradigm to study retrieval interference; and directly address the lack of linguistic diversity in the psycholinguistics literature.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
A major part of language comprehension is connecting words to the things they refer to. How speakers manage this feat so easily is a question of central importance for language science. To investigate this, psycholinguists use a range of experimental techniques to explore how pronouns and other referring devices direct a listener's attention to potential referents. Research in this area, typically on English and other Indo-European languages, has suggested that syntactic structure plays a major role in the process. Linguistic structure determines to a large extent where speakers expect to find a potential referent for a pronoun. One open question concerns how similar different languages are in this regard. Do speakers of diverse languages rely on fundamentally similar processes in real-time language comprehension?   

This project aimed to contribute to answering this question by exploring pronoun resolution in Tagalog. Tagalog is the lingua franca of the Philippines, spoken by more than 80 million people worldwide. Unlike in English and other Indo-European languages, some linguists have hypothesized that in Tagalog and other Austronesian languages, semantic relations (and not syntactic structure) play a major role in the process. In this project, the researchers combined traditional linguistic fieldwork with field-based psycholinguistics to explore the relative contribution of syntactic and semantic factors in how Tagalog speakers understand reflexive pronouns.

This project yielded a range of results that bear on this question. Through one-on-one work with language consultants and a large-scale interpretation questionnaire, the researchers observed that there was a striking similarity in the interpretations given to reflexive pronouns in Tagalog and English. In both languages, these pronouns were governed by syntactic information to a similar degree in interpretation questionnaires. Researchers in this project then used the visual world methodology to further explore this issue. This methodology uses rapid eye movements during language comprehension as an index of millisecond-by-millisecond attention. Using this methodology, the researchers observed that there was a disconnect between the early processes involved in interpreting these pronouns and the final interpretation of those pronouns in the offline questionnaires. The results suggested that Tagalog comprehenders considered semantically appropriate but syntactically illicit referents in the earliest moments of processing a reflexive pronoun. The visual world data suggests that the influence of syntactic information came to dominate semantic compatibility in speakers’ interpretations of the pronouns with more processing time. This finding suggests potential cross-linguistic differences in pronoun resolution, which will form the basis of further research that attempts to elucidate the exact semantic factors that direct Tagalog speakers’ attention in the early processing of reflexive pronouns.

 This project has both methodological and theoretical implications for research in this area. Methodologically, the successful application of the visual world methodology here provides further evidence that this tool can be used to probe early pronominal processing in auditory language comprehension. This is an important demonstration because the use of this methodology will allow researchers to work with a range of populations, such as speakers of languages without a literary tradition, in addressing similar research questions. Examining a range of different types of languages is critical for exploring the full diversity of how language processing proceeds. Theoretically, this methodology shows semantic interference in reflexive processing in Tagalog, a finding that has been hard (but not impossible) to observe in reading-based studies on English. This raises the question of whether Tagalog speakers might attend more to semantic features than syntactic features in early pronoun processing than English speakers do. Addressing this question is important for understanding how a person's language experience influences spontaneous and immediate processing of linguistic input. 

In terms of broader impacts, PI Pizarro-Guevara worked closely with researchers in the University of the Philippines Diliman, offering hands-on training in experimental methodologies to a range of native speaker linguists. This helps to broaden participation in psycholinguistic research. More broadly, the results of this research highlight the importance of under-studied languages in developing comprehensive models of human language comprehension.
